Summary: The event that killed my skepticism.
trends: There have been 15 other sightings in San Clemente
There were no other sightings in San Clemente on or around June 17th 2008
divs: sighting detailsmy friends and i were on a walk along san juan capistrano beach. it was about 2am, if i remember correctly. we were walking up a hill to a gazebo overlooking the beach and train tracks. suddenly there was a bright flash, and it quite frankly scared the shit out of all of us. i looked up and saw at first what i thought was a firework. at first my brain didn't process what i was seeing. the short of it is that it looked like someone had just waved a sparkler in the sky. as i said, at first i thought it was a bottle rocket, but there was absolutely no sound. that, and it didn't move in a forward direction like you'd expect a rocket propelled ordinance to do. it zigzagged backwards a little bit, then did an elaborate helix as it sped off to the north (over the small bay). then, as i stared at it, the light stretched itself out into a streak that vanished into the horizon with a snap like a rubberband... and then it winked out of existence entirely. the projectile\ufo\ whatever the hell it was had a white head. a bright oval shaped white ball of light at the front. however, unlike fireworks there wasn't any "lens flare" (a cross of light that accompanies most intensely bright lights) second, it left a trail of intensely bright magenta\red\orange light in its wake. when i mentioned the rubber band effect, the white head vanished super fast into the horizon and ducked behind a hill - while the red trail grew in intensity - and it looked like i was seeing multiple instances of an object being stretched over a great distance. when it "snapped" suddenly the trail of light closed in on the point in the horizon where the ball had vanished and suddenly the entire trail in the sky vanished. it was a pretty bright evening, nearly a full moon. there wasn't any vapor trail indicating rocket propulsion. the object felt like it was very close to us at first, but then when i stared at it i realized it was skimming along the bottom of the clouds. (the only way i could tell was that the light briefly bumped into the cloud layer during its travel) as i mentioned, there was no noise. absolutely none. no "pop" no explosions... and it was a very cold night. on nights that cold you can typically hear a car horn from 10 miles away on account of the density of air molecules. if it was a firework we would have heard it. im sending this to you guys because i'm hoping someone else saw the same thing. maybe someone can explain this. it's really been bothering me ever since.
